# Substitution variables match the column names of the rules converted to camelCase. For example: Target-Trait rule column value is represented as target substitution variable in hint text.
# Example substitution variables:
#    attribute - the name of the attribute being evaluated by a rule (for example: 'wings' or 'sex')
#    target - the target value for the rule (for example: for the wings attribute: 'wings' or 'wingless' and for the sex attribute:  'male' or 'female')
#    selected - the selected value for the rule (for example: for the wings attribute: 'wings' or 'wingless' and for the sex attribute:  'male' or 'female')
#    incorrectParent - this value is specified in the breeding rule sheets (mom | dad | parent)

LG1.C2a
Breeding

How can you change the [incorrectParent: mom's, dad's, parent's] alleles to produce a drake that [target: is shiny, has wings, has arms, has legs, is grey, has color, is hornless, has a nose spike, has deep color]?

[target: Shiny, Wings, Arms, Legs, Grey, Color, Hornless, Nose spike, Deep color] is a dominant trait. One parent must have at least one dominant [target: shiny, wings, arms, legs, grey, color, hornless, spike, deep] allele to produce a baby that [target: is shiny, has wings, has arms, has legs, is grey, has color, is hornless, has a nose spike, has deep color].

These parents cannot produce the target drake. Set at least one of [incorrectParent: the mom's, the dad's, each parent's] alleles to [target: shiny, wings, arms, legs, grey, color, hornless, spike, deep]. Sometimes it takes a while to get the target drake. Just keep breeding!

[target: Dull is, Wingless is, Armless is, Legless is, Orange is, Albino is , Horns are, Spikeless is, Faded color is, Short tails are] a recessive trait. Each parent must have at least one recessive [target: dull, wingless, armless, legless, orange, albino, horns, spikeless, faded, short] allele to produce a baby that  [target: is dull, is wingless, is armless, is legless, is orange, is albino, has horns, is spikeless, has faded color, has a short tail].

These parents cannot produce the target drake. Set at least one of [incorrectParent: the mom's, the dad's, each parent's] alleles to [target: dull, wingless, armless, legless, orange, albino, horns, spikeless, faded, short tail]. Sometimes it takes a while to get the target drake. Just keep breeding!

Let's think only about [attribute: tails]. There are three tails alleles. Long tails are the most dominant type of tail.

To produce a baby drake that has a [target: long, kinked, short] tail, change [incorrectParent: the mom's, the dad's, each parent's] alleles and see what happens!

Siblings
These parents cannot produce both sibling drakes. Look at the parents' [attribute: nose spike, deep color] alleles again.
[attribute: Nose spike, Deep color] is a sex-linked trait. Male drakes cannot pass their [attribute: nose spike, deep color] allele to their sons but they can pass this allele to their daughters!

Siblings
These parents cannot produce both sibling drakes. Look at the parents [attribute: tails] alleles again.
[attribute: Tails] is a gene with three alleles. Long tails are the most dominant and short tails are the most recessive. Kinked tails are dominant to short tails but recessive to long tails!
These parents cannot produce both sibling drakes. Change [incorrectParent: the mom's, the dad's, each parent's] [attribute: tails] alleles and breed again!
